entry.title: S/4HANA transition for US Federal Agencies
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP ECC, the solution designed for US federal agencies relies on the Public Sector Management (PSM) component and special ledger functionality. Extensions to PSM were introduced to support federal-specific processes and reporting requirements, such as the Global Treasury Accounting Symbols (GTAS). GTAS are identification codes that classify financial transactions for the US federal government, consisting of a three-digit agency identifier, a period of fund availability, and a main account specifying the fund’s purpose.

A key feature for public sector entities in SAP ECC is the use of special purpose ledgers. Ledger 95 is specifically reserved for handling US federal government transactions and maintains the split processor configuration. Together with Ledgers 96 and 97, it manages budgetary information and postings for federal accounting requirements. Because this functionality exists only through special ledgers in ECC, most federal agencies remained on classic G/L without the ability to migrate to parallel ledgers in New G/L.

In SAP S/4HANA, the universal journal replaces the special ledger functionality, with the additional information from Ledgers 95, 96, and 97 available as federal ledgers in ACDOCA. This shift creates a significant migration challenge: federal agencies running on ECC cannot pursue brownfield conversions as it cannot bring the information in special ledgers to the universal journal. Meanwhile, greenfield implementations require major investments of time and budget, and they do not support migration of detailed historical transactional data—often a regulatory requirement. Thus, neither brownfield nor greenfield options are viable.

Objective

The objective is to design a unique solution that meets the data migration needs of US federal agencies transitioning from ECC to S/4HANA. This solution must be able to extract splitting information from ECC special ledgers and apply it to the universal journal in S/4HANA, enabling migration of complete historical transactional data while ensuring business continuity and minimal change management.

Solution

SAP’s Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) organization has extended its Selective Data Transition (SDT) solution to specifically address the needs of US federal agencies. Often referred to as the “third option,” SDT provides an alternative to the traditional brownfield and greenfield approaches. It combines the strengths of both, offering flexibility in choosing the balance between reuse and redesign during S/4HANA transitions.

SDT leverages SAP DMLT’s proprietary software to design and execute tailor-made transitions. The key principle is separating application data from metadata (configuration, organizational structure, customizations, custom code, add-ons, etc.). The metadata is first used to create an S/4HANA shell, which can be deployed in a FedRAMP-authorized cloud environment.

During shell creation, federal-specific extensions such as the federal ledger, budgetary ledger, BCS, and budget period are configured. Once complete, the shell is ready to receive application data from the legacy ECC system.

For historical data migration, SDT tools have been extended to read selective history from ECC special ledgers and map it to the universal journal in S/4HANA. This allows complete transfer of historic transactional data, while ensuring alignment with redesigned federal-specific objects (e.g., mapping ECC tables FMUS* to S/4HANA tables PSGL*).

Note: Prior to data migration, the federal ledger and general ledger must be reconciled to ensure consistency.

Beyond federal extensions, SDT provides additional capabilities such as time-slicing historical data, harmonizing chart of accounts, and executing Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI) on the fly. Since the migration involves direct database loads, throughput is very high and optimized for large data volumes. SDT also includes advanced monitoring, error handling, and automated data validation, ensuring both efficiency and accuracy.

This approach is currently the only SAP-supported method for migrating historical transactional data from ECC to S/4HANA for US federal agencies.

Conclusion

SAP’s Selective Data Transition (SDT) offers a repeatable, automated, and secure solution for migrating historical transactional data from ECC to S/4HANA.

Key highlights of this solution include:

  • A hybrid approach that blends brownfield (reuse) and greenfield (redesign) strategies.
  • Extended SDT tools tailored for US federal agency requirements—the only SAP solution that enables historical transactional data migration.
  • Compatibility with FedRAMP-authorized cloud environments.
  • Mapping of special ledgers (95, 96, 97) to the universal journal in S/4HANA.
  • Direct database load approach ensuring maximum business continuity and minimal change management.
  • Ability to selectively migrate historical data and apply business-specific transformations on the fly.
  • A structured deployment process involving at least three iterative rounds of migration and validation before production cutover.

This solution, available through SAP services, has already been successfully deployed and being deployed at multiple US federal agencies, enabling compliance, efficiency, and business continuity in their transition to S/4HANA.

 

SAP S/4HANA #USFed #DMLT #SDT

entry.title: Re: Why is BOM Header Not Transferred to Project in Auto...
entry.content:
If your VC model is complete you do not need a PS Project to feed MRP requirements, that will come from the Sales Order requirement.  MRP will explode the BOM and handle all the lower level requirements.

There are other options depending on your business situation.

You can do a BOM transfer for lower level components if you need to order them immediately before the top level component is complete.  You can use Preliminary Requirements to prevent double ordering.

When you are ready to order the final VC material you can manually add it to the project and the same Configuration screen will pop up.  MRP will then explode this BOM and "consume" the preliminary requirements.

Technically you can also use BOM transfer for just the top level material (I'm not exactly sure how this would work if it is a Configurable material), but that's no different than adding it manually.

entry.title: New Developer- and SAP-Technology Forums/Groups
entry.content:
Dear "Application Development and Automation" group members/subscribers, 

In case you haven't seen the general announcement post that went out earlier this week, this blog post is to inform you that we launched a pilot of new developer- and SAP-technology related forums/groups this week.

For you, this means that while the pilot runs, the "Application Development and Automation" group is set to read-only.
We would like to encourage you to go to our new developer forums/groups, if you would like to ask or answer questions, or publish blog posts, on development/technology-related topics. 

There are a number of different reasons why we would like to test these new forums/groups: 

  1. Since our platform migration last year, we have received feedback that you didn't know where to go to find topics like ABAP, Integration or UI5. With these new developer forums/groups, we hope we have made it easier for you to find the technology topics you are most interested in.

  2. We noticed that the discussion board in this group was used to ask development related-questions. Generally, everyone has been very helpful answering questions asked here. However, our interest groups are for having conversations with, and connecting to, like-minded people around shared interests. This is why these groups have discussion boards (= for conversations) and blog posts, instead of Q&As/forums. Therefore, when someone asks a question in the "Application Development and Automation" discussion board, it is not possible for the author to accept the right answer as a solution. This again means, that if someone with the same problem comes to the community to get help later on, they will not be able to see what the solution to the problem was.
    Which brings us to no. 3 below:

  3. Because answers to questions in discussion (conversation) boards won't have accepted solutions, we are also not able to give credit to, or celebrate, the members who took the time to help answer questions.

  4. With the new developer forums, authors can accept any answer as a correct solution, which means we will be able to bring back our topic expert leaderboards, and give proper credit to our members who answer questions.

  5. A new denser forum feed, with no preview of content, making it easier to scroll down the feed to look for the questions you can help answer: 


  6. New filter for "Questions with no answers". 
    This long-requested filter has now been added to all new Developers forums, so that you can find all questions with. no answers on a specific topic with one click: 
  7. We can now highlight important product announcements, or other valuable content, you shouldn't miss, around your favourite development topics by using the "Featured Topics" section for the individual topics.

  8. Better subscription management.
    You will now be able to subscribe to either all developer/SAP-technology related content, or drill down to and only subscribe to the specific parts that interest you the most:
    1. Developers https://community.sap.com/t5/developers/ct-p/developers - here you can subscribe to the whole category, this subscription sends you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    2. The individual groups, with both the Forums and Blog posts - here taking ABAP Cloud as an example: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud/gh-p/abap-cloud - here you have the same subscribe option as above. If you subscribe to content here, it will send you notifications on the platform and email notifications according to your account settings. 
    3. The individual group boards, ABAP Cloud Forum: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-forum/bd-p/abap-cloudforum-board - here you have both the option to Subscribe and Subscribe to RSS Feed. The Subscribe option is the same as the two options above, and the RSS Feed is the one you are looking for. 
      You will find the same options for the blog posts boards as well: https://community.sap.com/t5/abap-cloud-blog-posts/bg-p/abap-cloudblog-board


If you missed the main announcement post, you can find more information in this What's New blog post. 

We hope you hop over to the new Developer groups to try them out 🙂 
If you have any feedback to us on the forums, you can provide it in the comments section on the What's New post linked above.

entry.title: Re: Exporting Plan Data from SAC to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
@Sotiris_X 

Export from SAC to ACDOCP in S4 is always in Overwrite mode. The plan data scope (or deletion scope) defines the plan data record set that will be reversed (overwritten) by the exported plan data record. Existing plan data in the SAP S/4HANA or S/4HANA Cloud system that contains any combination of the values of these dimensions will be reversed (overwritten) before the exported data is posted. You can control what data will be deleted by defining the plan data scope. You can refer to the below to understand how plan data scope can be used to control what data gets reversed before SAC data is loaded to S4.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/dd1d244504d44d928d3da20f710a7bd1.html

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Excluding Down Payments from CO Value Type 12 on WBS...
entry.content:
Why SAP Posts Down Payments to CO is because, SAP Project System (PS) is tightly integrated with CO. Any financial transaction on a WBS element (including down payments) is mirrored in CO to maintain a complete picture of project-related commitments and liquidity. Value type 12 (down payments): This is a statistical posting in CO. It doesn’t affect actual costs but ensures visibility for project reporting, budget checks, and cash flow analysis.

Why You See the Error (FI660) is because, when you omit customizing in OKEP (default cost elements) and KANK (number ranges for CO documents), the system cannot generate the required CO line item. SAP enforces this because every FI posting to a WBS must have a CO counterpart, even if only statistical.

So the Key takeaway is the note is “valid” for S/4HANA in terms of documentation, but the correction instructions are obsolete because the fix is already embedded in your release. That’s why you can’t implement it, and why SAP still enforces the CO posting logic for down payments.

So to conclude, the only supported workaround remains:

  • Maintain a dummy cost element in OKEP/KANK for KAZO.
  • Exclude that cost element (or value type 12) from your reporting and budget checks.

entry.title: Re: Why asset doest not have material code in SAP ERP?
entry.content:
Hello @nithin_pranesh 

What’s standard in S/4HANA Public Cloud (J62)? J62 covers the integrated asset acquisition process with purchasing; the asset master exists before GR, allowing GR/IR and invoice to link to the correct asset, which is how the J62 test flow is written

SAP’s External Asset Acquisitions describes the PO/invoice-integrated acquisition options; enrichment of the asset master is handled in Manage Fixed Assets afterwards. SAP Help Portal-External Asset Acquisitions

SAP KBA guidance for J62 prerequisites transfer date, etc confirms that the Public Cloud process is guided by the J62 setup, rather than by a “create at GR” switch. Currently, there is no documented setting to delay the automatic creation of GR.  SAP Support Portal-3119457 - Not able to create asset using the Manage Fixed Asset app - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Why serial and technical details often come later. Serial numbers and equipment can be created or assigned during Goods Receipt, after which those technical objects are linked to the asset. That’s why detailed identifiers are usually added after the PO. Learn SAP Dermo-How to Create Serial Numbers using a Goods Receipt

Bottom line confirmed. In Public Cloud with J62, the planned process is that the asset exists by the time you post GR and invoice; you then enrich missing fields later to manage the Fixed Assets equipment link. There is no SAP-documented option in Public Cloud to transfer the automatic asset creation from PO to GR.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: HCM Brasil - Crédito do Trabalhador - Provisão para o Terceiro Mês de Férias
entry.content:
Olá pessoal, 

Temos novidades empolgantes para compartilhar sobre o Crédito do Trabalhador! Para concluir as entregas previstas, estamos trazendo uma atualização significativa para a função de folha de pagamento BRPID, em conformidade com a Portaria 435/2025 do Governo Brasileiro. 

Provisão para Férias de Três Meses 

Agora, o sistema está preparado para lidar com férias que se estendem por três meses, o que pode ocorrer quando o funcionário inicia um período de 30 dias de férias em 31/01. Nesse caso, as férias podem abranger até 01/03. Com essa atualização, a provisão necessária para o terceiro mês também é realizada. 

Além disso, a funcionalidade existente permite realizar provisões para os meses subsequentes de férias utilizando a parcela correspondente ao mês atual. Isso garante que as operações de RH sejam mais eficientes e precisas. 

Para entender melhor essa solução, você pode consultar a SAP Note: 3655951 - eConsignado - Provisioning of IT3453 Amounts for Third Month on Vacation Payroll.

Essa melhoria faz parte do compromisso da SAP em apoiar os usuários de RH na otimização de suas operações. 

Se você gostou deste post, não esqueça de dar um Like e compartilhar com seus colegas. Para mais informações sobre o Crédito do Trabalhador, acesse nosso workzone exclusivo.  

Estamos ansiosos para ouvir seu feedback, comentários ou perguntas sobre este post. E não se esqueça de seguir a tag HCM Payroll Brazil na SAP Community para ficar por dentro das últimas novidades. 

Um abraço,   

Gabriel Pereira 

Time de HCM Brasil

entry.title: Re: Incorrect Creation Time Displayed in Billing Document...
entry.content:
Why the time mismatch occurs is because, SAP internally stores timestamps in UTC (Coordinated Universal Time). When you view a document in VF03, SAP converts this UTC time to your local time using the time zone settings configured in the system. If the time zone settings in your user profile or system configuration are incorrect or misaligned, the displayed time will not match your actual local time. This issue is not user-specific because the system-wide time zone configuration (application server or client settings) affects all users.

Areas to check

In SU01, under Default tab, check what time zone is maintained. Ensure, it reflects your local time zone.

Go to transaction STZAC to check the system time zone configuration. The system time zone should match the location of your SAP application server or be aligned with your business requirement.

Finally, refer to SAP Note 741734 for guidance on correcting time zone inconsistencies. Also review SAP Notes 481835 and 101726 for deeper analysis of UTC timer and time zone settings.

Good morning everyone,

I have several questions regarding the operation and licensing of SAP Business One in the Peruvian context, both at an accounting and contractual level.

Change of RUC and business name
If I acquire SAP Business One registered under a specific business name and RUC (Unique Taxpayer Registry), what happens if I later deactivate that RUC and business name? Is it possible to migrate all the information and licenses to a new business name and RUC, while keeping the same legal owner?

Support and maintenance

When I tried to regularize the situation with my partner, I was told that I was subject to a “lifetime” contract, despite not having used the system for the last 2 years. Is there any way to recover the licenses and be able to reinstall/migrate the system, considering that I need to change the hardware due to equipment failure?

Licenses as assets
I understand that SAP licenses are considered assets. Is it possible to sell, transfer, or move them to another company or individual?

I greatly appreciate any guidance, experience, or regulatory reference you can share, especially if you have gone through a similar case in Peru.

Best regards,
Marko

entry.title: Re: Unable to set user-defined currency type as a functio...
entry.content:
You cannot use a user-defined currency type (like Z1) as a functional currency in SAP because functional currency must be an FI-relevant currency type predefined by SAP, such as 10, 30, or 60 and that is why, you were getting the error FINS_ACDOC_CUST237. SAP only allows predefined currency types (like 10 = company code currency, 30 = group currency, 60 = global currency) to be used as functional currencies. User-defined currency types (Z) are considered freely defined currencies*, and SAP does not treat them as valid for FI postings or functional currency roles.

Having said that one option is stick with currency types 10, 30, or 60 for functional currency setup. If you need Z1 for reporting or analytics, you can still use it as a freely defined currency in the ledger — just not as the functional currency.

If your goal is to report in a different currency (e.g., USD for an INR company), use currency type 30 or 60 and configure the ledger to include that currency. For analytics, you can use Z1 in Universal Journal (ACDOCA) as a freely defined currency and build reports on it.

entry.title: PCR for PF Calculation Using Processed Basic
entry.content:
Dear Expert,

An employee has a basic wage type 1000 in Infotype 0008 with an amount of 30,000. He was on Leave Without Pay  (Action) for 10 days (11–15, 21–25) and therefore remained inactive during this period. After the factoring and storage process in the schema, the wage type 1000 amount is reduced to 20,322.58, which is working correctly.

The issue arises with the PF wage type 1101 in Infotype 0014. The PF is expected to be calculated as a percentage (e.g., 20%) of the employee’s factored basic pay. However, the system is not considering the factored basic (20,322.58) for the calculation.

Payroll Schema

Z023 - (storing the basic salary after factoring)

The factored basic salary is not being stored in BVER. I believe this is the issue, as the value cannot be read 

ZREC - ( PF calculation rule)

If I use the code mentioned below, only the amounts for Basic01 and Basic02 are read; it does not work for general employees.

AMT+E 1000 - 9,677.42
AMT+R 1000 - 5,806.45 

 

The PF should be calculated as 20% of 20,322.58 = 4,064.52, but this adjustment is currently missing.

Kindly review and suggest a solution.

@sikindar_a

entry.title: Re: Mass creation of RFQ in S/4 hana system
entry.content:
Hello,

In the Manage RFQs app, you can only create one RFQs at a time. Also, there is no app to create RFQs in bulk. 
More details can be found in KBA 2115337.

You can evaluate with your local Consultant Team the possibility of developing a custom solution using APIs. Detailed information about this feature can be found on this SAP Help page: Request for Quotation - Create, Update, Delete

Best regards, 
Tatiana

entry.title: SAP BTP CI CD service for on premise S4 HANA systems RICEFW applications
entry.content:
Hi,

Can we use SAP BTP CI CD service for premise S4 HANA systems RICEFW applications deployment? There are only 4 pre-configured pipelines (Cloud Foundry Environment, SAP Fiori for ABAP Platform, SAP Integration Suite Artifacts, Kyma Runtime )available in CI CD service.  Which pipeline to use for this on premise scenario?

Example scenario :

On premise ABAP objects development like ABAP programs written in SE38, data dictionary objects created in SE11, enhancements, smartforms, webservices etc are developed in on-premise SAP S4 HANA development system. The transport request numbers are released and are pushed to Github repository via gCTS fiori app as commits.  SAP BTP CI CD pipeline job should trigger and perform the automated testing and deployment to target on premise systems(not the subaccounts but to on premise target systems like QA and production).

How to design this on-premise scenario with SAP BTP CI CD pipeline? How to automate and configure ATC checks, unit tests, integration testing, end to end testing?

Can anybody please provide inputs?

Regards,

Sunil

entry.title: Re: CAT2 is showing error message
entry.content:
Hello @Anas71 

For S/4HANA Public Cloud, please note that CAT2/KP26 are not available. The KL001 code generally indicates that the cost center–activity type master is missing for the current fiscal year.

To fix this, create or extend TMOD↔1020001 in Manage Activity Types set for 2025 and update the 2025 price in Maintain Activity Price. Afterwards, test with Post Direct Activity Allocation. Also, verify that the cost center category allows activity allocation and that CO periods are open. If problems persist.You can raise an incident with all relevant details to SAP.

You can watch this useful SAP VIDEO SAP Help Financial Planning-Coster Center Activity Cost Rate Calculation-Video

SAP KBA 2864151 – Cost Center Category for Activity Types in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  Why it is necessary for the cost center category to allow activity allocation.

SAP KBA 3108513 – CR091 error when inputting activity type into Work Center This isn't your exact message, but it includes important checks on activity types, CC assignments, and their validity.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Extensibility in the Age of AI: Why ABCD Is Easier (and Smarter) Than You Think
entry.content:
The CTO’s Concern

Not long ago, during a client conversation, a CTO expressed a concern that resonated deeply:

“We need to extend our system. But every time someone says ‘let’s customize this,’ I feel we’re piling risk. And now with AI coming, I’m afraid our mess gets worse.”

That statement captures the heart of a challenge many SAP customers face. Customization has been both the strength and the Achilles’ heel of enterprise landscapes. It allows us to adapt, innovate, and differentiate — but it often comes with technical debt, upgrade pain, and hidden complexity.

Why Extensibility Matters More in the AI Era

Let’s pause here. Ten years ago, if you added a Z-table or tweaked a user exit, the worst-case scenario was some testing pain during an upgrade. Today?

  • If your data model is inconsistent, your AI forecasts won’t align with reality.
  • If your logic is buried in old exits, Joule copilots can’t “see” your processes.
  • If your core is brittle, cloud updates feel like risks, not opportunities.

In other words: extensibility is no longer just about “making it work.” It’s about making AI possible.

And now, with SAP’s AI ambitions accelerating — embedded copilots, Joule agents, and business data clouds powering predictive intelligence — the messy customizations of the past risk becoming blockers for the future.

This is where ABCD extensibility comes in. Far from being abstract jargon, it’s a practical compass to guide enterprises on how to extend the system smartly, safely, and in a way that enables AI instead of hindering it.

The ABCD Levels: A Human Explanation

SAP’s ABCD framework doesn’t exist to confuse us — it exists to help customers navigate the grey space between innovation and stability.

Here’s the official breakdown, with real-world translation:

A Short Story: The MV45AFZZ Debate

Anyone who has worked in SAP Sales and Distribution knows the legendary include MV45AFZZ. For decades, it’s been the go-to spot for developers to implement custom sales order checks, validations, and logic.

At one client, a senior developer proudly said, “We’ve been using MV45AFZZ for 15 years, and it works just fine. Why change?”

And he wasn’t wrong. In many ways, that’s a Level B extensibility choice: small, controlled, and serving the business well. (In fact, SAP even documented this in SAP Note 3578329, proving that not all ‘old-school’ practices are bad.)

The problem comes when dozens of such exits pile up, undocumented, with overlapping logic — and suddenly the system feels like a house of cards.

Here’s the twist: ABCD extensibility is not about banning MV45AFZZ or exits. It’s about putting them in the right place, with the right intent.

The IDoc Question: Clean or Not?

One of the most common debates I hear is: “We use IDocs everywhere. Are they clean core?”

The answer: Yes, IDocs are safe — they fall under Level B.

SAP clarified this in the IDoc Clean Core blog.

Why? Because IDocs are:

  • Officially documented.
  • Supported by SAP.
  • Used for integration and still relevant in S/4HANA.

That said, if you’re starting a greenfield cloud project, you may want to move toward APIs and Event Mesh (Level A) instead. But if you’ve got an existing landscape with IDocs, don’t panic — they’re not “unclean.”

Real-World Scenarios: Which Level to Choose?

Why This Matters for AI

AI copilots like Joule don’t “guess.” They rely on:

  • Stable APIs (Level A).
  • Clear data models (A & B).
  • Trusted logic (not buried in Level C/D).

If your system is full of Level D hacks, AI copilots won’t understand your processes. But if you steer toward A and B (with C monitored), you create an AI-ready enterprise.

 Closing Thought

Extensibility is not the villain. Misuse is.

The ABCD framework gives us a shared language:

  • A when we want innovation + AI without worry.
  • B when proven frameworks like IDocs or MV45AFZZ still serve us.
  • C only if there’s no choice — and we track it closely.
  • D only if we want to leave a headache for the next generation.

So next time someone says “let’s customize,” you don’t need to panic. You just need to ask:

Is this A, B, C, or D? And that one question can mean the difference between a system that blocks AI — and one that accelerates it.

#SAPCleanCore #SAPExtensibility #ABAPCloud #SAPAI #SAPBTP #S4HANACloud #IDoc

//Ingo

entry.title: How to have unified HU in EWM?
entry.content:
Currently, in my scenario, I have a 1-to-1 configuration for HUs. That is, if there are 200 units of an item in stock, 200 HUs will be generated.

The requirement is to have a HU with a higher quantity. I achieved this via PACKSPEC. However, when another receipt arrives, it generates another HU, and I want it to add the items if the existing HU has space.

Any tips on how to do this?

Currently, my minimum process is:

Purchase requisition -> Purchase order -> Receipt -> Blind Count (RFUI) -> PRDI

Immediately after the blind count, the HU is generated along with the tasks in PRDI.

entry.title: Urgent Purchasing with Purchase Requisition Workflow in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud-1
entry.content:
Introduction:
In the world of procurement, speed can sometimes matter as much as compliance. Purchase Requisitions (PRs) are great for capturing business needs, but let’s be honest—there are moments when waiting for the usual approval cycle simply isn’t an option. Maybe it’s a critical spare part, or maybe a project deadline is on the line. Whatever the case, you need a way to move things along quickly, without breaking governance rules.
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud already gives us a pretty solid workflow framework for PRs. The catch, though, is that the standard setup doesn’t always capture those urgent, real-life situations. And that’s exactly where extensibility comes into play.
This blog shows you how to extend the workflow by adding a custom condition called “Urgent Purchasing.” With this in place, whenever a PR item is marked as urgent, the system knows to push it straight to the right approvers—helping you strike that tricky balance between speed and control.
Business Requirement:

  • Create a new Purchase Requisition (PR) approval workflow for Urgent Purchasing line items
  • Trigger the PR workflow only when this condition is true
  • Keep it flexible so it can be reused or adapted later

Process Flow Approach:
To meet this requirement, the standard extensibility options in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are utilized:

  • Custom Field → A checkbox field at the PR item level to flag whether it’s “Urgent Purchasing”
  • Custom Logic → To define and evaluate the start condition for the workflow
  • Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisition App → To configure the condition into the workflow

Step 1: Creation of Custom Field for Purchase Requisitions:
Created a custom field for PR items using the Custom Fields app.
Process:
Go to Custom Fields → click + (Create)

Fill in the following:

Business Context: Procurement: Purchase Requisition Item (MM_PURREQN_ITEM)

  • Label: Urgent Purchasing
  • Identifier: UrgentPurchasing
  • Tooltip: Urgent Purchasing
  • Type: Checkbox

After creation, the relevant UIs, reports, and analytics are enabled. The new field is added to the UI by adapting the screen and adding the new field.

Adding and Verifying the Custom Field in Purchase Requisition:
Click on Adapt UI → Add the Custom Field →Verify the Custom Field “Urgent Purchasing”.

Step 2: Adding “Urgent Purchasing” As a Start Condition to the Workflow for Purchase Requisition:
This step defines the 'Urgent Purchasing' condition, so that it appears as a start condition in the workflow configuration.
Creating Custom logic for the “Urgent Purchasing” as below:
1. Process Flow: Go to Custom Logic App → Click on Create → Enter the Following Information.
2. Business Context: Procurement: Start and Pre-Conditions in Flexible Workflow
3. Extension Point: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF
                                                                                Click on Step 2:
Click on the Add Button:
SCENARIO_ID: WS02000471
                                                                                Click on Step 3:
Implementation Description: Providing Additional Conditions for Scenarios
Implementation ID: YY1_PURCHASEREQUISITIONITEMS

            Click on Create and Publish
            Click on Open Editor and write the logic for “Urgent Purchasing”

Logic Code:
DATA: ls_condition LIKE LINE OF ct_condition,
ls_parameter LIKE LINE OF ct_parameter.

" Condition 1: Urgent Purchasing
ls_condition-id = '1'.
ls_condition-subject = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_condition-type = if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_def=>cs_condtype-start_step.
APPEND ls_condition TO ct_condition.

ls_parameter-id = '1'.
ls_parameter-name = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_parameter-shorttext = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_parameter-xsd_type = if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_def=>cs_xstype-boolean.
ls_parameter-mandatory = abap_false.
APPEND ls_parameter TO ct_parameter.
Verifying the “Urgent Purchasing” at “Start Condition” of Purchase Requisition Workflow:

Step 3: Create Evaluation Custom Logic for Workflow
Once the condition existed, I needed logic to evaluate whether it was true for a given PR item.
Evaluation logic for the “Urgent Purchasing” is as follows:
1. Process Flow: Go to Custom Logic App → Click on Create → Enter the Following Information.
2. Business Context: Procurement: Start and Pre-Conditions in Flexible Workflow
3. Extension Point: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL

                                                                                  Click on Step 2
Click on the Add Button:
SCENARIO_ID: WS02000471
                                                                                 Click on Step 3
Implementation Description: Evaluation Logic for Purchase Requisition Workflow Condition
Implementation ID: YY1_EVALUATIONLOOPB_WPR

           Click on Create and Publish
          Click on Open Editor and write the logic for “Urgent Purchasing”

Logic Code for Evaluation:
" BAdI: Evaluation of Workflow Conditions for PR Item

DATA: ls_item TYPE i_purchaserequisitionitemapi01.

cv_is_true = abap_false.

" Ensure we have both PR and Item key
IF is_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1 IS INITIAL OR
is_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_2 IS INITIAL.
RETURN.
ENDIF.

" Read the specific Purchase Requisition Item
SELECT SINGLE *
FROM i_purchaserequisitionitemapi01
WHERE purchaserequisition = @IS_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1
AND purchaserequisitionitem = @IS_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_2
INTO @LS_item.
IF sy-subrc < > 0.
RETURN.
ENDIF.

" Condition 1: Urgent Purchasing
IF is_condition-condition_id = '1'.
" Adjust according to how the extension field stores the flag
IF ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = 'X'
OR ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = abap_true
OR ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = 'true'.
cv_is_true = abap_true.
ENDIF.
ENDIF.

Step 4: Creation of Workflow based on Custom Field
Use the Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions app to add the new start condition.

  • Navigate to the workflow scenario.
  • Add the custom condition Urgent Purchasing.
  • Define the workflow steps (e.g., approval by the Urgent Purchase owner).

Results:
After putting this together, PR workflows are now automatically triggered if an item is flagged as urgent purchasing.
Some key benefits:

  • 100% in-app extensibility, no modifications to SAP standard objects
  • Business-specific conditions integrated seamlessly with the standard workflow


Conclusion:
This small enhancement really shows the power of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud extensibility. By combining custom fields and logic with flexible workflows, it’s possible to adapt standard processes to unique business needs—without complex development.
If your organization faces similar challenges with urgent purchasing, compliance, or approval rules, this approach is worth considering.

Faisal Abbas

Application Cosnultant SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud

Navigator Business Solutions

entry.title: October 2 Employee Central Live Session
entry.content:
Thank you to everyone who attended the Employee Central Live Session on October 2. 

This session was the second part of the five-day Employee Central Workshop series, which focuses on activating the core functions of Employee Central from scratch. 

Here's a brief summary of Day 2—Configuring Foundation Objects:

  • The Foundation Objects Configuration Workbook serves as a baseline for capturing customer requirements related to Foundation Objects
  • The tools used for configuring XML-based Foundation Objects are:
    • Corporate Data Models
    • Manage Organization Pay and Job Structures
    • Import Foundation Data
  • The tools used for configuring MDF-based Foundation Objects are:
    • Configure Object Definition
    • Manage Data, 
    • Import and Export Data
  • Composite Associations are used to create a parent-child relationship
  • Valid-When Associations are used to establish hierarchy levels in the organization structure
  • The order of data import depends on the associations configured between the objects.

You can find the presentation when you log in to https://learning.sap.com. Go to My Learning > Live Sessions. 

Thank you.

entry.title: October 1 Employee Central Live Session
entry.content:
Thank you to everyone who attended the Employee Central Live Session on October 1. 

This session was part of the 5-day series Employee Central Workshop which focuses on activating the core functions of Employee Central from scratch. 

Here's a brief summary of Day 1- Provisioning and Other Initial Configurations:

  • The list of provisioning settings to enable Employee Central's core functionality is listed in the Implementing Employee Central - Basic Settings section
  • A super admin is created in provisioning to create a security administrator who will then manage the RBP groups and roles
  • The set of standard picklists called "Master Picklist" must be uploaded to support the fields that have picklist references
  • The four data models used in Employee Central must be uploaded in this order:
    • Corporate Data Model
    • Country-specific Corporate Data Model
    • Succession Data Model
    • Country-specific Succession Data Model

You can find the presentation when you log in to https://learning.sap.com. Go to My Learning > Live Sessions. 

Thank you.

entry.title: From Penalty to Power Play: Why Identity Management Is Key to Better Customer Experiences
entry.content:
A few weeks ago, a friend bought tickets to a hockey game and wanted to transfer them to me. Like many people, we went with the quickest workaround—she shared her login credentials so I could access the tickets. But what should have been a simple process turned into several days of password resets, missed messages, and back-and-forth. By the time I finally got into her account, the tickets were gone. She had attempted to transfer them during the delay, but amid the confusion and technical issues, I never actually received them. If I had been able to log in right away, I could have just downloaded them directly. But the access issues created confusion, and without any clear support from the platform, we ended up losing the tickets—and missing the game.

It was a simple plan that fell apart because of something as basic as account access.

This experience is a small example of a much larger issue in digital commerce: the friction that arises when identity management isn’t built with the customer in mind. It’s easy to overlook, but poor identity experiences lead directly to lost opportunities—not just for consumers, but for the businesses trying to reach them.

 

Identity Friction = Lost Revenue

In today’s commerce landscape, customer expectations are sky-high. If a login process is confusing, if an account is hard to access, or if personalization feels off—people walk away. And often, they don’t come back.

Poor identity experiences hurt businesses in more ways than one:

  • They interrupt the buying journey. Whether it’s a login loop, a forgotten password, or a complicated checkout flow, friction at these key points drives abandonment.
  • They block personalization. When customer data is fragmented across systems, it’s hard to deliver the tailored experiences that today’s buyers expect.
  • They erode trust. Without clear consent management and transparency, customers hesitate to share information—or stop engaging entirely.
  • They slow down growth. Outdated systems and homegrown solutions often can’t keep up with omnichannel strategies or evolving compliance needs.

For a deeper dive into how SAP CIAM can help reduce identity friction, join us at SAP TechEd on November 6 for a dedicated CIAM security session. Register here to secure your spot and learn more.

 

Where SAP CIAM + Commerce Cloud Make the Difference

Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) helps solve these challenges by making identity work for the customer—not against them. When integrated into your commerce ecosystem, CIAM doesn't just handle sign-ins—it actively supports better customer relationships and business outcomes.

Here’s how:

  • It reduces friction at every stage—from anonymous browsing to account creation to repeat purchases. The experience becomes smoother, simpler, and more secure.
  • It improves conversion by enabling personalized, real-time engagement without relying on clunky data handoffs or third-party cookies.
  • It builds trust by giving customers control over their data, preferences, and permissions—while helping businesses stay compliant across regions.
  • It supports scale by integrating identity across every digital touchpoint, enabling consistent experiences on web, mobile, in-store, and beyond.

In short, CIAM allows businesses to move away from fragmented, frustrating interactions and toward a unified customer experience that feels intuitive, safe, and relevant—every time. To hear firsthand how SAP customers are achieving this with SAP CIAM and Commerce Cloud, join us at SAP Connect in Las Vegas on October 8. Register here to attend.

 

The Takeaway

In commerce, moments of friction are more than just annoyances—they’re missed opportunities. Whether it’s lost hockey tickets or lost revenue, the cause is often the same: a broken identity experience.

Modern CIAM, especially when combined with a powerful commerce platform, turns identity into an asset. It streamlines the journey, protects the user, and empowers businesses to engage with clarity and confidence.

And the best part? It just works—so your customers don’t have to. 

Learn more here.

entry.title: Re: confidential enterprise projects
entry.content:
Hello @tomlovelock 

Besides Chris's comments, restrict access to ETO/defence projects so that only users with a “users assigned access basis can view them.

Follow this process below

Assign the project to an Authorisation Group in the Enterprise Project field.

In' Maintain Business Roles, ' set Restrictions → Read to' Restricted' for the project apps, and specify the allowed Authorisation Group values for each role.

For highly sensitive work, set Confidential Project to true and keep a small, designated project team; only authorised roles and members will see it.

This concludes the process; there is no necessity for cost-center modifications. Conduct a test using two roles—one inclusive of the group value and the other excluding it—and verify visibility.

Authoritative references

  • Maintain Business Role Restrictions – how to restrict by fields (set Read to Restricted and keep values). 
  • SAP Help Portal-Identity and Access Management-How to Define Authorisations Based on Restrictions
  • Enterprise Project CDS (I_ENTERPRISEPROJECT) shows AuthorizationGroup and ConfidentialProject fields used for the controls above. SAP Business Accelerator Hub-I_EnterprisedProject(Basic)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Customizing Your PDF with the Categories of Class A Invoices
entry.content:
Hello!  

In this blog, we will walk you through the steps of designing the new PDF templates using Adobe LiveCycle to remain compliant with R.G. N° 5762/2025 and R.G. N°5764/2025 for Argentina. 

If you carry out sales, work placements or provision of services in Argentina using print character M for VAT-registered taxpayers, according to resolution R.G. N° 5762/2025 and R.G. N°5764/2025, as of December 1, 2025, you must replace the existing class M invoices with the new categories of Class A invoices: 

Categories of Class A Invoices 

Description 

What you need to do 

Standard Class A 

For taxpayers meeting all fiscal and solvency requirements 

Nothing 

Class A with legend “OPERACIÓN SUJETA A RETENCIÓN” 

For taxpayers who do not meet certain requirements 

You design a new PDF template 

Class A with legend “PAGO EN CBU INFORMADA” 

For taxpayers who may not meet solvency criteria, requiring payments to be made to a specific, declared bank account (CBU) 

You design a new PDF template 

Prerequisites: 

  • You have Adobe LiveCycle Designer on your computer and know how to design forms with this tool.  
  • You have assigned the Extensibility (SAP_CORE_BC_EXT) authorization role for your user.  

Procedure: 

1. Access the Maintain Form Templates (F1434) app.  

2. Go to the Predelivered Templates tab and search for the following PDF form:  

Document Type: 

Print Char A, B, E 

Form Template Name: 

EDO_AR_PRINT 

Data Source: 

EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03 

3. Open the form template and select Download.  

4. Extract the downloaded ZIP file and open the .xdp file in the Adobe Livecycle Desginer.  

5. In the Adobe LifeCycle Designer, choose the Master Pages tab.   

6. From the Object Library, drag and drop a Text onto the PageType box of your PDF. (Note: We suggest placing the Text on the bottom left corner of the PageType box.)  

7. On the Hierarchy tab, select the new field (default name Text1) and open the context menu (right-click or press Shift+F10). Choose Rename, type Legenda, and press Enter.  

8. Edit the new Legenda text. Insert the respective text value: “PAGO EN CBU INFORMADA” or “OPERACIÓN SUJETA A RETENCIÓN”. 

9. On the Hierarchy tab, select the content field. 

10. After selecting the content field, open the Script Editor (default shortcut Ctrl+Shift+F5) and insert the following Javascript logic to configure Legenda field:  

if (this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.var_PrintChar").rawValue == 'A' ) { 
  this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "visible"; 
} else { 
this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "hidden"; 
}

11. Save and name your template. 

12. Access the Maintain Form Templates (F1434) app. 

13. On the Custom Templates tab, choose New. Create a custom template for your form by making the following settings:  

  • Form Template Name: Enter a name for your form template.  
  • Language: Select the language of your form template.  
  • Select Form Template File: Upload the file that you've created in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.  
  • Data Source: EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03  
  • Form Type: Choose Standalone.  

14. Save your form template.  

15. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the Configure Printing Form for eInvoice (103277) configuration activity and assign your custom form template to the relevant eDocument type and branch.   

And that's it!

You can now open the eDocument Cockpit and submit your document. The PDF form templates you created contain the new categories of Class A invoices for VAT-registered taxpayers. 

Was this post helpful? Leave a like (kudo) and share the content with your colleagues. Feel free to leave feedback, comments, or questions in the space below.    

For more information, go to Document and Reporting Compliance for Argentina on the SAP Help Portal and make sure to follow SAP Document and Reporting Compliance.    

 

Regards, 

João Pedro Braun Agnes & Pedro Brum
